III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4125 Personal possessions; money; clothing;
Section storage space.
Description (1) A licensee shall have a written policy that designates all of the
following:
(c) The method for ensuring that each resident has sufficient
clean, properly fitting, seasonal clothing.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Upon admission Youth B was only allowed underwear to wear for
several days while quarantining.
Investigation Youth B is a temporary court ward who was court-ordered into
treatment at Maurice Spear Campus on 9/19/22. According to
Chief Administrator (CA), since his admission, the Complainant,
Youth B’s mother, has made numerous false accusations against
the facility. Complainant promised to “do whatever it takes” to get
her son out. On 2/28/2023, she sent an ambulance to the facility
for Youth B even though he was not in the building and was
working off-site. CA said he explained to paramedics Youth B
was not there and that no one from the facility had called them.
Since Youth B’s admission, the facility Nurse said she has been
consistently available and has responded to all of the
Complainant’s concerns about her son. Rather than utilize the
facility’s written grievance process Complainant has chosen to
make verbal complaints. Moving forward CA plans to participate
in all future contacts between the Nurse and Complainant to
witness and document what occurs.
2

In addition to issues with this facility, CA said Complainant is well
known to the local county courts and juvenile justice personnel.
This year she contacted a newspaper with allegations against
another juvenile facility and the paper wrote a damaging article
about them. CA said the court is currently considering limiting
Complainant’s contact with her son and Maurice Spear Campus
staff to once weekly during visiting hours and family therapy as
she is interfering with his treatment. For these reasons, I did not
contact the Complainant to seek additional information regarding
her concerns.
I interviewed Youth B at the facility on 3/2/23. Upon admission in
September 2022, he said he spent five days in detention on
quarantine due to COVID. During this time Youth B said he was
given a wool blanket and only allowed to wear underwear. Asked
if he was given a smock, he responded, “I didn’t need a smock.
They only give those to kids who attempt suicide.”
I observed the youth rooms in the detention building but no youths
were present. Each room had a mattress, mattress platform,
blanket, and pillow. I also observed the suicide gowns referred to
as “smocks.” The smocks are the same color (dark green) and
made from the same heavy quilted material as some of the
blankets. CA said it is protocol that youth wear their underwear
and are provided with blankets in quarantine. They are also
routinely offered a smock but can choose not to wear it. Since it is
part of the regular routine, it would not be documented that Youth
B was offered and refused to wear a smock.
Analysis In quarantine Youth B said he wore his underwear and was given
a wool blanket. He said did not need a suicide smock.
Facility protocol is that youth are allowed to wear their underwear
and a suicide smock (made of heavy quilted material) in
detention/quarantine. While he may have refused to wear it, there
is no evidence Youth B was not allowed to wear a suicide smock
in addition to his underwear.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

Rule Code & Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth B has ringworm, skin issues, a finger injury, breathing
issues and a chipped tooth, none of which have been treated.
Youth B was forced to attend school with a fever. Youth B found
blood on his pillow on 2/26/23.
Investigation On 3/2/23, I observed a faded pink semi-circular rash the size of a
half-dollar on Youth B’s right bicep. He denied that it itches. I
asked Youth B about ringworm. He said the Nurse gave him
topical cream, but it did not resolve the problem. After that Youth
B saw a dermatologist who identified the rash as ringworm and
prescribed another topical cream. Youth B said the cream
prescribed by the dermatologist also does not work and that he
will know it worked when the rash disappears.
Regarding the skin on his feet, Youth B said he has bumps and
itching between his toes otherwise known as athlete’s foot. He
has been using over-the-counter anti-fungal cream twice daily
since 10/19/22. He said the cream “doesn’t work” but he has not
informed the facility nurse.
The facility staffs a full-time registered nurse (Nurse) and a Family
Nurse Practitioner (FNP) who provides weekly in-person
consultation.
On 9/20/22, an initial health screening indicated Youth B has “red
patch on right arm – onset 9 months ago. Saw Dr. who didn’t
recommend Tx.”
On 10/26/22, Nurse noted “follow-up athlete’s foot. Continue
cream as ordered. See FNP next visit.” A consult form by FNP
dated 11/1/22 indicates Youth B’s “sole of right foot erythematic
skin; cracked scaley: 2” diameter round red scaley patch on his
right upper arm, presumptive Tinea Corporis (ringworm) of ten
months. Referral to Dermatologist.”
On 11/15/22 Nurse noted “Re-visit rash to arm. Continue
antifungal to feet twice daily, started antifungal to arm twice daily.
4

If released, make referral to dermatology per Probation Officer.
Mother aware. If goes to O/U, make appointment.”
On 12/5/22 Nurse noted “review use of athlete’s foot cream. Non-
use: resident reports ‘not working.’ Continue to keep in place.
Dermatology in place.”
On 1/5/23 Nurse noted “rash on feet and arm, tinea pedis; tinea
corporis. Ketoconazole 2% cream twice daily until clear. Keep
feet dry.”
Medication logs indicate Youth B used antifungal cream for foot
and arm from 10/24/22 through 1/5/23 and Ketoconazole 2% from
1/6/23 to present.
I interviewed Nurse on 3/2/23. She has worked at the facility for
three years. Nurse said Youth B saw a dermatologist on 1/5/23
who ordered a prescription antifungal cream that youth has used
since 1/5/23. Nurse said a follow-up dermatology appointment is
scheduled on 3/14/23 for both the ringworm and athlete’s foot.
In December 2022, Youth B said he injured his right index finger,
was x-rayed and given a splint. Upon observation, the finger
appears to have healed crooked. Youth B said he was seen again
at urgent care and directed to continue wearing the splint during
the night, but he decided to stop wearing it. He seems resigned to
the fact his finger is crooked and stated, “there’s nothing I can do
about it.”
On 12/28/22, Nurse noted “right pointer finger injury with
basketball net. Discussed with FNP. Urgent care visit for x-ray.
Spoke with mother (Complainant).”
On 12/28/22, Youth B was seen at Adrian Urgent Care and
diagnosed with “Mildly displaced fracture of middle phalanx of
index finger, initial encounter for closed fracture – uncomplicated.
Prescribed Ibuprofen three times per day for pain. Referred to
ortho. No sports until evaluated by ortho. Copy of x-ray sent with
patient.”
On 12/29/22, Youth B was seen by an orthopedic surgeon who
indicated “Stax splint around the clock. Ok to remove to shower.
Change powerflex wrap daily. Return visit 2/2/23 @ 10:30am.”
5

On 2/2/23 Youth B saw orthopedic surgeon for follow up who
indicated “ok to remove splint during day and work on range of
motion. Wear splint at night recommend 6 weeks.”
Nurse said Youth B has a follow-up appointment with the
orthopedic surgeon on 3/16/23.
For five weeks, Youth B said he has been experiencing breathing
difficulties due to congestion. He was given over-the-counter
nasal spray, Claritin and Zyrtec, but the problem continues.
Medical professionals believe he has allergies or possibly a
deviated septum. Youth B said he is scheduled to see an ears,
nose and throat specialist later this month.
On 1/23/23, Nurse noted Youth B was seen for “sinus congestion.
Two sprays each nare – 4 times as needed. Over-the-counter
nasal spray.”
On 2/10/23, Youth B was seen by FNP who noted “feels like
something is up in right nare causing congestion but nothing
blows out. Was using saline nasal spray. Has seen small amount
blood from left nostril. Denies other symptoms. Assessment:
Chronic Rhinitis exacerbated by low humidity environment of
winter. Recommend: Claritin or Zyrtec per standing orders; may
apply tiny amount of triple antibiotic ointment inside nares.”
On 2/21/23, Youth B was seen by FNP who noted “for Rhinitis –
Loratadine trial ineffective- still sniffling. Staff reports even at night
while asleep. Denies cough, nasal discharge clear. Recommend:
D/C Loratadine; Begin trial of Zyrtec x 7 days per standing orders;
Will consider ENT referral if Zyrtec ineffective. Reassess in one
week if better or worse.”
On 2/28/23, Youth B was seen by FNP who assessed “ongoing
Rhinitis possibly secondary to deviated septum; possible
allergies.” Recommend: Called mom…is very concerned about
cardiopulmonary status. Spoke with mom for approx. 30
minutes… ENT referral asap.
Nurse said Youth B has an ENT appointment scheduled on
3/24/23.
Youth B said he chipped a back molar and a dentist “filled it.”
There are no pending issues with his teeth.
6

On 1/19/23 Nurse noted Youth B had a dental visit. “Mom wanted
to be notified of care given/decisions made by dentist especially if
root canal needed. Follow up with receptionist stated Dr. would
only need to cap tooth. Mom made aware and agreeable.”
A youth dental exam form indicated the dentist examined Youth B,
took x-rays, and filled his tooth on 1/19/23.
Youth B said in December 2022, he was “really sick and needed
to see a doctor but all they gave me was Ibuprofen. The next
morning, I could barely move. The nurse made me go to
school…A doctor would have given me actual medicine, not
Ibuprofen.”
Nurse noted that staff informed her on 12/18/22 after-hours that
Youth B had a 100-degree fever and Tylenol was administered
with a positive effect. The next morning (12/19/22) Nurse saw
Youth B and noted “no fever at this time. Covid test negative. Has
been resting since 3pm yesterday. Recommend: Up for school –
rule out cold virus, start Musinex over the counter twice daily until
resolved, monitor temp, increase fluids, Tylenol, or Ibuprofen per
protocol for achiness (parents aware). On 12/20/22 Nurse noted
“rechecked; reports feeling better.” On 12/21/22, Nurse noted
“checked ears, complained of earache, assessed ears, no
concern. Have FNP recheck at next visit.”
On 12/19/22, after seeing him in the morning and his temperature
was normal, Nurse said she made the decision Youth B was well
enough to attend school that day.
On 2/26/23, Youth B said he woke up and there was blood on his
pillow. Nurse indicated a nosebleed would not be uncommon due
to the dry winter air conditions combined with Youth B’s constant
“sniffling.” “Over the counter nasal spray ordered.”
Analysis Even though his athlete’s foot, the rash on his arm and nasal
congestion persist, there is no evidence Youth B’s medical issues
are not being treated or addressed. He has had multiple
appointments with the facility nurse and FNP and has been
treated by general physicians, a dentist, dermatologist, and
orthopedic surgeon.
The facility’s nurse and FNP have been in continuous
communication with Youth B’s mother, the Complainant, and
continue to follow up with his ongoing medical concerns. Follow-
up appointments are scheduled with his dermatologist and
7

orthopedic surgeon on 3/14/23 and 3/16/23, respectively and he is
scheduled to see an ear, nose, and throat specialist on 3/24/23.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
